author: Jasper Hamill
title: Migrants were an issue in the Ice Age too: What made cavemen flock to British shores?
text:
British scientists have launched an investigation into an Ice Age migrant crisis which saw huge numbers of cavemen arrive on British shores.
Experts from the University of Leicester are now digging at an ancient campsite set up by " economic migrants " an estimated 15,000 years ago.
They hope to discover exactly why tribes of Ice Age hunter-gatherers upped sticks from their European homes for a new life in England.
Lynden Cooper, principal investigator, said: “The people who left behind these clues were members of a small group of pioneer mobile hunter gatherers who repopulated north-west Europe towards the end of the last Ice Age with the rapid onset of a warmer climate and the development of open grassland vegetation.
"They were re-colonising lands that had been lost for circa 10,000 years - economic migrants in a period of rapid global climate change, if you like."
Getty Home sweet home: Cavemen moved to Britain in huge numbers more than 15,000 years ago
Cooper is currently excavating a site at Bradgate Park, Leicestershire, which he described as "the equivalent of a Pompeii, preserving a record of human existence from a snapshot in time millennia ago".
The prehistoric encampment was only preserved because the area around it was declared a deer park in medieval times and left uncultivated.
It is thought the ancient migrants came to England in search of a better life of easy meat and good hunting.
"The new environment attracted a rich fauna of large vertebrates including wild horse and red deer, two of the preferred prey species," Cooper added
"Other species included mammoth, elk, wild cattle, wolf, arctic fox, arctic hare and brown bear."
Getty Mod cons: Stonehenge was built in about 2600 BC, a long time after the Ice Age migrant crisis
So far, Cooper has found flint dating back to the Late Upper Palaeolithic era, but he hopes to find spear tips, knives and other tools in the coming weeks and months.
This will allow him to sketch an unprecedentedly detailed image of life in Stone Age Britain.
Peter Tyldesley, director of the Bradgate Park Trust, added: "Whilst the medieval and later history of Bradgate Park is well documented, we are only just beginning to uncover the fascinating story of this area in prehistoric times.
"We are delighted to be working with University of Leicester’s Archaeological Services to secure this nationally important site and ultimately to tell its story to our visitors."
